header_summary:
The recent updates across various versions of Bitcoin Core highlight the community's ongoing efforts to enhance and stabilize the software. Gloria Zhao announced the availability of Bitcoin Core version 29.2rc2 for testing, emphasizing its role in refining the platform before the final release ([Bitcoin Core Release](https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-29.2/test.rc2/)). Similarly, fanquake introduced version 30.0rc3, marking significant progress towards the final launch of version 30.0, with detailed release notes and a testing guide provided to assist contributors ([Bitcoin Core Progress](https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-30.0/test.rc3)). Ava Chow's announcement of version 28.3rc1 as a step towards a new major release further underscores the continuous development cycle of Bitcoin Core, aiming for reliability and performance enhancements ([Bitcoin Core Update](https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-28.3/test.rc1/)).

In a different discussion, ZmnSCPxj delves into the optimal management of storage devices for data integrity and security, advocating for the use of Trusted Execution Environments (TEEs) to minimize operational complexity and enhance system reliability ([Storage and Security Discussion](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/persisting-mutable-storage-inside-the-t-ee/2029/3)). This approach is highlighted as superior to conventional redundancy strategies, focusing on resilience against device failures and minimizing risks related to key management.

Moreover, an analysis by JoseSK999 reveals a significant trend in blockchain data composition, with approximately 53% of all block data originating from witnesses over the past four years. This statistic underscores the vital role of witnesses in validating transactions and maintaining the integrity and functionality of blockchain networks, reflecting their importance in upholding the decentralized nature of these systems ([Blockchain Data Analysis](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/witnessless-sync-for-pruned-nodes/1742/3)).

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 29.2 Release Candidate 2 Available
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version 29.2rc2 is now available for testing.
- The update introduces minor changes and improvements accessible for review on GitHub.
- It moves closer to becoming the official v29.2 release after testing feedback.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 30.0rc3 release candidate is available
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core's version v30.0rc3 release candidate is now available for testing and review.
- A comprehensive guide and release notes are provided to support detailed evaluation and feedback.
- Successful testing without major issues will lead to its final release as version 30.0.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 28.3 Release Candidate 1 Available
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version v28.3rc1 is now available for download.
- Preliminary release notes for this update can be found online.
- No critical issues will mark it as version v28.3 officially.

recent_posts.title: Persisting Mutable Storage Inside The "T"EE
recent_posts.summary:
- The debate explores optimal storage management, comparing TEEs' resilience to traditional redundancy methods.
- TEEs offer simplified operation, minimizing complexity and enhancing system reliability without holding private keys.
- The strategy ensures high security and availability, negating encrypted tunnels in favor of cryptographic signatures for integrity.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core v29.2 release candidate available
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core's latest release candidate, version 29.2rc2, is now available.
- Users and developers can access it through provided links for download and GitHub review.
- If testing finds no significant issues, it will become the official version 29.2.

recent_posts.title: Witnessless Sync for Pruned Nodes
recent_posts.summary:
- Recent analysis shows 53% of blockchain data comes from witnesses over four years.
- Witnesses are key in validating transactions and maintaining blockchain integrity.
- Their role is central to blockchain functionality, emphasizing trust and decentralization.

active_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] Mempool Validation and Relay Policies via User-Defined Scripts
authors: [BIP Proposal] Mempool Validation and Relay Policies via User-Defined Scripts Aiden McClelland
active_posts.summary:
- Aiden McClelland proposed a new Bitcoin Improvement Proposal for a modular mempool/relay policy.
- The proposal aims to reconcile Bitcoin community conflicts by avoiding node forks.
- McClelland faces challenges implementing the BIP due to a long break from C++ programming.

active_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] Limit ScriptPubkey Size >= 520 Bytes Consensus.
active_posts.summary:
- Brandon Black proposes a Bitcoin soft fork to limit ScriptPubkey size for enhanced security.
- The change targets negligible current utilization but aims to improve scalability and mitigate risks.
- Feedback is sought from the Bitcoin community to balance innovation and operational efficiency.

active_posts.title: On (in)ability to embed data into Schnorr
active_posts.summary:
- AdamISZ explores embedding data in Schnorr signatures, highlighting potential security risks.
- He concludes embedding compromises UTXO set integrity by revealing private keys.
- The analysis prompts broader discussion on blockchain security and invites feedback.

active_posts.title: Response to Pieter Wuille's StackExchange Answer Re: Nuking the Opreturn Filter
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin's fee estimation process is fraught with complexities and uncertainties.
- Efforts to standardize mempools may inadvertently push Bitcoin towards vulnerability.
- A shift towards broader network-wide heuristics is encouraged to embrace inherent transaction variabilities.

active_posts.title: Eclipsing Bitcoin Nodes with BGP Interception Attacks
active_posts.summary:
- A study exposes vulnerabilities in the Bitcoin network to stealthy BGP hijacking and eclipse attacks.
- Attackers can intercept Bitcoin traffic by manipulating BGP routes, enabling potential abuses like double spending.
- Proposed defenses include peer rotation, dynamic port negotiation, and enhancing route diversity to counteract such attacks.

active_posts.title: Optimal Threshold Signatures in Bitcoin
active_posts.summary:
- Threshold signatures secure Bitcoin with a required number of validations, balancing security and access risk.
- Optimal threshold calculation considers security enhancements and usability to minimize loss.
- Dynamic models adjust thresholds over time for changing security conditions, guiding Bitcoin's secure transaction management.

today_in_history_posts.title: Test cases for Taproot signature message
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- A pull request for the Bitcoin Improvement Proposals repository was opened by Caironi.
- Caironi and Wuille discussed the clarity and test vector issues for Taproot in BIPs.
- Wuille supported integrating Caironi's test cases for Taproot into Bitcoin Core and the BIPs.
contributors: [bitcoin-dev] Test cases for Taproot signature message Giacomo Caironi

today_in_history_posts.title: Lightning over taproot with PTLCs
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The Lightning Network protocol is updating with a focus on PTLCs and reduced data needs.
- The update includes support for HTLCs, uses musig techniques, and adds transaction layers.
- Challenges in claiming funds and the need for preliminary work on musig standards are highlighted.

today_in_history_posts.title: Thoughts on scaling and consensus changes (2023)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin scaling proposes 50,000 off-chain "bitcoin banks" for 1 billion weekly users.
- Concepts like Utreexo aim to optimize, but hybrid systems preserving Bitcoin's integrity are likely.
- Infrastructure must ensure regulatory compliance, quick Layer 1 exits, and simplifying custodial tasks.
